Thirdly, Birth: which depending on
one of the other sources, can claim no
principle of justification but what they
possess, nor even so much, as the innocent
children can neither be considered
as debtors nor enemies.
The history of the Africans presents
us with an additional source, a disgraceful
commerce, in which the slaves are
bought at a public mart, stowed together
as the common cargo of the vessel,
without regard to decency, cleanliness,
or health, and cast over-board in case
of short allowance or danger, without
reluctance or pity. For the support of
this commerce recourse is frequently
had to violence, or fraud, and it is an
indisputable fact, that, besides the temptation
which a constant market for slaves
holds out to the avarice, or the intemperance
of the natives, arts have frequently
been practised to foment wars
